comments:
From Eclipse Corner:
Ok, I believe I have it figured out:
I have open (yet saved) a .java file with a breakpoint in it.
I run the debugger, which stops at the breakpoint.
I kill (using the stop button) the application.
I make ANY change to the file (add a single space at the end of the comment
etc) and I can save it, but not format. Formatting results in an error - see
attached log file)

I have been hitting this in more complex code, but was able to repeat the
problem in the small included file as well, so I doubt it is the result of
some strange code I wrote (but, never discount that either).

The test case is:
[package testing;
import java.util.*;
public class TestClass {
 public static void main(String args[]) {
  TestClass x = new TestClass();
  x.doStuff();
 }

 public void doStuff() {
  ArrayList temp = new ArrayList();
  for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++)
   temp.add(new Integer(i));
  boolean didWeBreakHere = true;
 }
}]

The .log contents is:

I cannot reproduce this problem for now. I tried in 205 and 137 without any 
success. Wait for more information from the original reporter on Eclipse Corner.

Here are the steps to reproduce in a 137 workspace:

0. Click on the button "Show Source of Selected Element Only".
1. Place breakpoint and run the debugger.
2. Click on the highlighted line when the debugger hits the break point
(making no changes to the code, but the view switches from the whole class
to just the member that contains the breakpoint.
3. Terminate the app.
4. Format the code. Save the code.
5. Run the debugger again. Once it starts (or tries) I get 2 dialog boxes
indicating errors (log included).

Following these steps, I could reproduce the original failure. I'll see if the 
problem occurs in a 2.0 workspace.
I reproduced the problem in a 205 workspace. I will investigate.

It doesn't seem to be directly related to the formatter. In fact if you close 
the windows in the debugger that shows the code of the method doStuff() after 
the step 3, it is not possible to reproduce the problem. It looks like this is 
an refresh problem of the contents of the existing window after the formatting. 
The field myLength doesn't seem to be updated and then the test: pos + length > 
myLength fails.
See the extracted code below from the class 
org.eclipse.jface.text.AbstractDocument.
	/*
	 * @see IDocument#get
	 */
	public String get(int pos, int length) throws BadLocationException {
		int myLength= getLength();
		if ((0 > pos) || (0 > length) || (pos + length > myLength))
			throw new BadLocationException();
		return getStore().get(pos, length);
	}

I think when the contents of the document is updated. Its child documents should 
be updated as well. It think this is a problem in JFace according to the stack 
trace.
